bibl.title: Letter from Grace T. Hallock to Philip Showalter Hench, September 23, 1940

div1.p: Hallock responds to the alleged historical inaccuracies, which Hench has noted, in her Metropolitan Life Insurance-sponsored filmstrip and pamphlet about Reed.

div1.head: Letter from Grace T. Hallock to Philip Showalter Hench, September 23, 1940
div1.opener:
METROPOLITAN LIFE INSURANCE COMPANY
FREDERICK H. ECKER, Chairman of the Board
LEROY A. LINCOLN. President
NEW YORK CITY
September 23, 1940
WELFARE DIVISION
----
DONALD B. ARMSTRONG, M.D.
Third Vice-President
ANTHONY J. LANZA, M.D.
Assistant Medical Director
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you very much indeed for your comments on the Walter
Reed material. I was not in the least disturbed by your reference to var-
ious inaccuracies. Indeed I am very glad that you took the trouble to point
them out. I am sorry that I misinterpreted your reference to the pictures
of Camp Lazear. I had not seen the filmstrip for some time and, since you
had been speaking of the pamphlet in the preceding paragraph, I jumped to
the wrong conclusion. You are absolutely right about the picture. We are
about to make an extensive revision of the Walter Reed filmstrip and I shall
certainly see that this mistake is rectified. When the filmstrip was pre-
pared I was not with the Company, and my only connection with it was the
preparation of the first draft of the scenario and correspondence with various
individuals who might have photographs that could be used. The material for
the filmstrip was collected by our Film Bureau. It was made some time ago -
1927, I believe - but there may be records available of sources of some of
the photographs. If you have not been able to locate Mrs. Reed at either
one of the two addresses I gave you in my letter of September 5th, I am
afraid that I cannot help you locate her. I visited Mrs. Reed in Washington
in the winter of 1927 and I had some correspondence with her subsequently,
but I have not heard from her in some years. In regard to the diagram in
the pamphlet, picturing the experiment in the infected mosquito building,
it probably would have been better to have followed the documentary accounts
exactly. The booklet was written 15 years ago in 1925 and I remember that
I was particularly impressed at the time with the clear-cut definition of
the problem and its solution, as given by Gorgas. Since then I have learned
the wisdom of going back to the sources in gathering material for popular
consumption. In making clear to high school students the significance of
the problem in question, the diagram seems to have been very effective. It
can readily be altered in the revision of the filmstrip and, if there is
ever occasion to revise the pamphlet, I shall seriously consider making the
change.

I was in Cuba in the fall of 1923. I am sure that the
site of Camp Lazear pointed out to me was the one which you describe as “the
false one.” I was in Cuba as a casual tourist and was not at that time par-
ticularly interested in Walter Reed and the history of yellow fever, so my im-
pression was entirely uncritical. I am glad to learn that you and Mr. Moran
- 2 -
Dr. Philip S. Hench
September 23, 1940
have located the true site and I hope you are taking steps to have it recog-
nized as such. I had the pleasure of talking to Mr. Moran when he was in
New York for the opening of the play “Yellow Jack.”

I am glad to send you additional copies of the pamphlet on
Walter Reed. This booklet is one of a series and, as you may be interested
in reviewing the other biographies in the series, I am sending you also under
separate cover one copy of each.
